Not sure which section to put this in so I figured IQ, guy with chalk board, education.......
 
 http://www.cnn.com/2010/HEALTH/02/26/liberals.atheists.sex.intelligence/index.html
 
 
Liberalism, atheism, male sexual exclusivity linked to IQ
 
 (CNN) -- Political, religious and sexual behaviors may be reflections of intelligence, a new study finds.
 
 Evolutionary psychologist Satoshi Kanazawa at the the London School of Economics and Political Science correlated data on these behaviors with IQ from a large national U.S. sample and found that, on average, people who identified as liberal and atheist had higher IQs. This applied also to sexual exclusivity in men, but not in women. The findings will be published in the March 2010 issue of Social Psychology Quarterly.
 
 The IQ differences, while statistically significant, are not stunning -- on the order of 6 to 11 points -- and the data should not be used to stereotype or make assumptions about people, experts say. But they show how certain patterns of identifying with particular ideologies develop, and how some people's behaviors come to be. 

 
 
Bailey also said that these preferences may stem from a desire to show superiority or elitism, which also has to do with IQ. In fact, aligning oneself with "unconventional" philosophies such as liberalism or atheism may be "ways to communicate to everyone that you're pretty smart," he said. 

 
 

 Participants who said they were atheists had an average IQ of 103 in adolescence, while adults who said they were religious averaged 97, the study found. Atheism "allows someone to move forward and speculate on life without any concern for the dogmatic structure of a religion," Bailey said. 

 
 An interesting study since the IQ tests were taken as children while the conservative/liberal labels were derived after the children grew up. I have seen this about a dozen places and have not yet seen what definition they used for "conservative" and whether or not they took the persons word for it or had a series of questions to establish their conservative credentials. 
 
 To me that would be critical because most intelligent people I know who are traditional conservatives no longer apply the conservative label to themselves, preferring to be identified as independents, libertarians, or TRADITIONAL conservatives, lest they be classed in with the mouth breathing Bush supporting XXXXXX who, as we have covered before, are typically more liberal in most of their stances than Bill Clinton.
 
 Thoughts???

Evolutionary psychology is a funny thing, it often amounts to "I can conceive of a plausible mechanism whereby X would have evolved, and therefore X evolved by this mechanism". I usually don't give much weight to evolutionary psychology's arguments, they're often speculative or circumstantial. Not that this is really evolutionary psychology, the explanations for why this result occurred could be.
 
 There's something I like to called the crud factor, Meehl (1990) "everything correlates to some extent with everything else".
 
 Everyone is partly right about the causes and effects, for some of the people. Every cause you can imagine for the relationship is true, in a small way.

 I still think that it would depend on your definition of "conservative" and "liberal".
 
 Currently the viewpoints that are commonly being labeled as "conservative" are not so much "conservative" as they are stupid and simple minded. For example, a lot of people would claim that cutting off all social programs would be a "conservative" stance to take when in reality it would just be foolish since anybody capable of complex thought would recognize that the reason we HAVE those social programs is that it is cheaper in the long run to feed people than it is to fight them, and because there is a pretty good economic incentive to keep a portion of your population unemployed (think wage requirements and workforce portability). The trick is to keep them enemployed so you have your labor force liquidity covered without having to drive around in armoured vehicles surrounded by macyhine gun toting guards to keep them from robbing you.
 
 This has really been a fairly recent phenomenon. Traditionally I think conservatives have taken realistic, well thought out positions even if they were not always popular. Of late it seems like the label "conservative" should be replaced with "simpleton" since anything that required complex thinking is automatically labeled "liberal" by those claiming the conservative label.
Steeeeve

I still think that it would depend on your definition of "conservative" and "liberal".

The trick is to keep them enemployed so you have your labor force liquidity covered without having to drive around in armoured vehicles surrounded by macyhine gun toting guards to keep them from robbing you.
 
 This has really been a fairly recent phenomenon. Traditionally I think conservatives have taken realistic, well thought out positions even if they were not always popular. Of late it seems like the label "conservative" should be replaced with "simpleton" since anything that required complex thinking is automatically labeled "liberal" by those claiming the conservative label.

 I could see it going a few ways with social programs. At one level social programs create a government power which is desirable by those seeking power (obviously) thus they tend to get bigger and include more. You don't want to get into a pattern with too few people in the workforce which drives up wages making jobs got to India thus putting more on the unemployment line. Really, here, we are talking about too many different things. You have SS, Medicare, and unemployment (which covers a lot I know). Unemployment/welfare benefits are generally limited and should be and a good conservative (good Scotsman fallacy!) would see this as a benefit to society but would also be ready to tear down the white house walls if it expanded. Social Security and Medicare/Medicaid are currently just not working out but not many solutions exist to fix this that are viable. I'm not even saying something close to these isn't needed...just that the current format is terrible.
 
 Point taken though. We need to get away from one level thought which looks like the below:
 Military = good = get more of it
 
 or on the democrat side of things
 
 poor people exist = give them money = no more poor people will exist
 
 Both are wrong.

 As much as I would like to believe this I just can't. The first thing I noticed is in 94-95 they took IQ of kids in grades 7-12. In 00-01 the interviewed the participants aged 18-28. They are 4 years top heavy (assuming 18 yrs for 12th grade).
 
 They do define somewhat conservative and liberal but limit it to issues that are not the typical hot buttons for conservatives (gun control, abortion) as well as things typical of younger people (concern for unrelated people, change). This watered down ideology I think skews the results
 
 It isn't clear what other data was used but to draw a conclusion from such a short period of time and targeting a group that typically leans towards a liberal affiliation makes it hard to take this seriously. 
 
 I would be interested in seeing results over a longer time period or the same time spread over several decades as well as targeting older people. Then maybe they have something to talk about.
 
 Although oddly despite all the problems they are still right. 
 
 Couldn't resist :p emoticon_smile

 I should particularly like to take an intense look at California and how it was run into the ground by conservative extremists. It began in 1978 with Prop 13:
 
Proposition 13 (officially titled the People's Initiative to Limit Property Taxation) was an amendment of the Constitution of California enacted in 1978, by means of the initiative process. It was approved by California voters on June 6, 1978. It was upheld as constitutional by the United States Supreme Court in the case of Nordlinger v. Hahn, 505 U.S. 1 (1992). Proposition 13 is embodied in Article 13A of the Constitution of the State of California.
 
 The most significant portion of the act is the first paragraph, which capped real estate taxes:
 
 
Section 1. (a) The maximum amount of any ad valorem tax on real property shall not exceed One percent (1%) of the full cash value of such property. The one percent (1%) tax to be collected by the counties and apportioned according to law to the districts within the counties.

 
 The proposition's passage resulted in a cap on property tax rates in the state, reducing them by an average of 57%. In addition to lowering property taxes, the initiative also contained language requiring a two-thirds majority in both legislative houses for future increases in all state tax rates or amounts of revenue collected, including income tax rates. It also requires two-thirds vote majority in local elections for local governments wishing to raise special taxes. Proposition 13 received an enormous amount of publicity, not only in California, but throughout the United States.

 California Proposition 13 (1978) - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
 
 Then, there was the Bush/Cheney Enron debacle which led to the election of Schwarzenegger, Republican, which appears not to have helped matters in California at all: 
 
 
Enron defrauded California out of billions during energy crisis
 By Jerry Isaacs
 10 May 2002
 Documents released Monday by the Federal Energy Regulation Commission revealed Enron Corporation deliberately created real and imaginary shortages during the 2000-2001 California energy crisis, in order drive up prices and reap vast profits in the state's newly deregulated energy market.
 
 Internal memos from the now bankrupt company outline the various schemes Enron executives used to defraud officials running the state's power grid, manipulate energy supplies and literally loot the state treasury of billions of dollars. Throughout this period Enron enjoyed the closest political ties with the Bush White House, which rejected appeals from California officials for federal intervention and the imposition of price caps.

 Enron defrauded California out of billions during energy crisis
 
 Normally I would quibble with a purely socialist look at Enron's history but they pretty much are on the mark -- after all, I was around during that time and that's what really happened.

It forced utility companies to sell off their electricity generating equipment and buy electricity at market rates. Then it fixed the rates in California, making out-of-state sale preferrential.  Net Savings ... 185.2B......... -642.0B
 Net Borrowing ... 184.7B......... -785.1B
 Disposable Income .. . 7.7B......... 3.9B
 
 So receipts increased, but not from businesses. Under Rep we paid more in taxes with less money. In 8 years disposable income (adjusted) was cut in half. Spending was close to doubled (well over the increase in receipts). We went from lending 185B more than we borrowed to borrowing 785B more than we lend and turned a 185B surplus into a 642B deficit. We entered 2 wars which we are still in and suffered the the greatest attack on US soil by foreign persons since the British when there wasn't even a US yet.
 
 I don't think Obama has yet equaled Bush in incompetence, granted at times it may seem as if he is trying, but he was handed a lousy set of circumstances.

 
 Can you show me where the disposable income number came from?

 This shows a different story if you are referring to personal disposable income.
 
 If you want to look at personal income tax you have to look at personal disposable income.

Comparing an economy that Bush was handed vs what Bush left it is obvious you just want to bash Obama because he is a democrat. 
 
 The information I provided showed economic factors at the end of Clinton's term and the end of Bush's term. Bush walked into a manageable situation. By the end of his 1st year he took net lending/borrowing from +146B to -65B and to -422B the following and just to make things even better we went from -395B at the end of 2007 to -933B at the end of 2008. Net Government savings went from +226 to +24 to -306 by his second year and in 2007 was -214 only to skyrocket to -682 in 2008. 
 
 I would not be surprised to find out Bush intentionally tanked the economy to leave Democrats to figure it out. It's perfect everybody remembers the good times under Bush, Obama catches the flak, Rep fight everything insisting things have to be done their way, but don't say what that way is. Elections time comes and it's all the Dem fault for not fixing things and Rep win campaigning on the terrible times.

It is important to note that the numbers being used do not include our "off balance sheet" items (SS, medicare, etc....) or unfunded liabilities. 
 
 Personally I think it is kind of XXXX how Obama has more or less gotten a pass on his spending. While I can agree that he was handed an unprecedented situation, his response to it has been decidedly poor and expensive. 
 
 Democrats need to stop passing it off as "fixing Bushs mess". The economy is not Bushs mess. What we are seeing is the inescapable result building an economy on quicksand. IT is nasty, it is ugly, and it is FAR from over. We will look back on the last couple of years as the LEAD UP to the downturn. 
 
 Republicans need to stop giving him a pass on his spending as well. A lot of republicans have been hesitant to do so because he has shoe horned a bunch of that spending into Bush programs and they dont want to give the impression that they are criticizing those programs that they once supported.
 
 Of course they did not make any sense and they were a bad idea when they supported them before, so they are certainly a bad idea now that they are even bigger, but partisan XXXX and the inability to admit a mistake is keeping most republicans out of it (and possibly the fact that they are all special interest whores and dont want to upset their pay masters who have largely been the beneficiaries of the largess).

I think a reasonable person would come to the conclusion that the US screwed themselves and Congress/Presidents from the last 15-20 years helped.

daewoo

I think a reasonable person would come to the conclusion that the US screwed themselves and Congress/Presidents from the last 15-20 years helped.

 We screwed ourselves with Reaganomics. The country was in an economic slide, and it was one that we needed in order to have a realistic, firmly grounded economy. Reagan came along and used massive public spending and debt to slow/stop the slide. That was the original bubble. All those following were mostly to cover the inevitable results of that.
 
 With Bush Sr the US public showed that they were willing to enjoy the illusion of prosperity at any expense. Bush SR was the only president we had in the last 20 years that had a realistic economic view and the courage to take steps to address our problems.
 
 We quickly voted him out of office. 
 
 Clinton was probably the second best president in the last 20 year when it comes to economic stewardship, but then with the massive influx of capital from the dot com bubble, he could spend money like a drunken sailor in a whore house and still have a "balanced" budget (maybe not quite, but a lot closer than anybody else came). 
 
 Baby Bush and Obama have just been nightmares. There was nothing AT ALL that was good about Bush Jrs time in the white house. It was an unmitigated disaster. Obama is looking about the same.
